comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: Daniel Guggenheim (July 9, 1856 – September 28, 1930) was an American industrialist and philanthropist, and a son of Meyer Guggenheim. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Guggenheim

comment.author: 40147761@N04
comment._content:
Richard, Thank You for all your input on these photos. It makes them so much more interesting and easy to access for some of us. 
Have question, There appears to be a date on the lower left edge of this one I can't quite make out. I think it reads  __/17/17. Maybe you can make it out . My eyes are to old and tired. Again Thank You.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
I think that date may be 1912. LOC could check on the original negative to be sure.

His brother, Benjamin Guggenheim, drowned in the sinking of the Titanic, April 20, 1912.

comment.author: 34911459@N08
comment._content: The date is quite hard to read, but I think it's 9/17/1912.  Thanks for spotting it, Mona.

comment.author: 40147761@N04
comment._content:
No, I thank you. I am honored to participate. However in saying that I have restudied the photo and am convinced the year is 1917. The top of the 7 is too square to be a 2. But the day of the month is rounded, it could be a 12.  That 9 is backwards to the other numbers, (it messes with me. ) 9/12/17 looks good to me.  
Maybe we'll get lucky and find where it was used, and it may remain a mystery. Either way It Is History..
I  truly enjoy this stream.

comment.author: 40147761@N04
comment._content: From the other photo: Harry Angstrom said: Wikipedia article. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Guggenheim

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content:
A very hard date to decipher!  After checking the super-size TIFF file at the Library's site (linked through the Persistent URL), the date seems to be  "6/15/25."  Bain staff some times wrote a date reflecting usage rather than initial creation, so that might account for the discrepancy with the photo that Lu spotted, where the date is clearly earlier,  "8/6/1913."

The year "1913" fits well the surrounding negatives, so we'll go with that.
